repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This can happen (rarely) with exceptions very early in the
module init process.

Fixes #4377

I also cleaned up a few inline functions to have return statements.

~I'm struggling to see how to add a test for this (so I've
omitted it) but happy to take any suggestions~ Test is included now

comment_data.body: I don't think this is necessary. And note that the NumPy project owns this file now. We shouldn't apply changes on our side without pushing them there first.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -988,13 +988,13 @@ cdef inline object get_array_base(ndarray arr):
 # Cython code.
 cdef inline int import_array() except -1:
     try:
-        __pyx_import_array()
+        return __pyx_import_array()

comment_data.body:
It doesn't globally use the `stringtab`, though, just one specific entry from it: the function name that we pass below.

We currently use `char*` for the function name and file path, which is admittedly suboptimal, but could simplify this code since we don't actually need the `stringtab` for that. I'm unsure, though, because I'd rather like to use prepared Python strings than `char*` in the future.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3096,7 +3096,15 @@ def generate_module_init_func(self, imported_modules, env, code):
             code.put_xdecref(cname, type)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_cname)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_dict_cname)
+        # We can run into errors before the stringtab is initialize.
+        # In this case it is not safe to add a traceback (because it uses the stringtab)

comment_data.body: It's actually `__pyx_n_s_cline_in_traceback` in `__Pyx_CLineForTraceback` that it uses (i.e. it's nested pretty deep in the traceback generating code, and I wouldn't like to guarantee that it's the only one).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3096,7 +3096,15 @@ def generate_module_init_func(self, imported_modules, env, code):
             code.put_xdecref(cname, type)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_cname)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_dict_cname)
+        # We can run into errors before the stringtab is initialize.
+        # In this case it is not safe to add a traceback (because it uses the stringtab)

comment_data.body: Good to know. Still, my general review comment still applies that there's a cleaner way to do this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3096,7 +3096,15 @@ def generate_module_init_func(self, imported_modules, env, code):
             code.put_xdecref(cname, type)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_cname)
         code.putln('if (%s) {' % env.module_dict_cname)
+        # We can run into errors before the stringtab is initialize.
+        # In this case it is not safe to add a traceback (because it uses the stringtab)

comment_data.body: I've undone this - while I think it would have been clearer I don't think it's worth the effort of changing in two places
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -988,13 +988,13 @@ cdef inline object get_array_base(ndarray arr):
 # Cython code.
 cdef inline int import_array() except -1:
     try:
-        __pyx_import_array()
+        return __pyx_import_array()

comment_data.body: Why not use separate functions (and sections) for these? E.g. `InitGlobals`, `InitStrings`, `InitConstants`, or something along those lines. There isn't really a reason why they should all share the same section, except for laziness. And that now gets in the way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1138,7 +1138,8 @@ class GlobalState(object):
         'pystring_table',
         'cached_builtins',
         'cached_constants',
-        'init_globals',
+        'init_globals',  # init_globals generates an init_globals_body insertion point
+            # that comes before the utility code

comment_data.body:
Right - I've split this into two `init_globals` (defines function `__Pyx_InitGlobals`) and `init_constants` (defines function `__Pyx_InitConstants`). The main reason I didn't split it into three with a separate `InitStrings` function is that there was already a `__Pyx_InitStrings` function, and I was struggling to come up with a clear name to distinguish them.

That's still slightly lazy, but I think the main thing is that the utility code has its own section.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1138,7 +1138,8 @@ class GlobalState(object):
         'pystring_table',
         'cached_builtins',
         'cached_constants',
-        'init_globals',
+        'init_globals',  # init_globals generates an init_globals_body insertion point
+            # that comes before the utility code

commit.message:
Avoid AddTraceback is stringtab isn't set up

This can happen (rarely) with exceptions very early in the
module init process.

Fixes #4377

I also cleaned up a few inline functions to have return statements.

I'm struggling to see how to add a test for this (so I've
omitted it) but happy to take any suggestions

Added test

Use a make Numpy module to make a version of "import_array"
that always fails

Moved numpy check after stringtab, used flag

to avoid checking if entire stringtab is initialized
Split init utility code into a separate function

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Avoid AddTraceback if stringtab isn't set up
